reviewText: This nearly two-hour potpourri of car commercials and promotions features the American Big Three automakers in the period from about 1940 to the mid-sixties, as well as brief but witty vintage commercials from the Sixties for the Renault Dauphine, the VW Beetle and Hertz.If you like cars, or if you just gravitate to the quaint and the camp, this DVD is well worth having.  Do you think "product placement" is a recent attribute of movies or TV news?  Check out Chevrolet's mock-newsreels, and its Max Fleischer-style cartoons, ca. 1940, which always got one of their models into the action.  Watch the evolution of car advertising from practicality (the "economical" 1953 Chevrolet with its "blue flame" six-cylinder engine) to machismo (especially an ad for the 1965 Mustang, in this case a vivid orange one).Undoubtedly, though, the two standouts on this disc are short features based on General Motors' "Motorama" shows of 1956 and 1961.  The latter, "A Touch of Magic," comes across a little flatfooted; it's basically a closed-set studio confection with little or no footage of any of the real Motoramas GM held in 1961 (and that was the last year).  Stars of the show are two Rob-and-Laura-Petrie type suburbanites who go back in time to the Middle Ages (a great deal of time to waste on a metaphor of old "magic" versus new technological magic); then back to the present for their first houseparty with invisible guests but very visible new GM models in the driveway and gleaming Frigidaire heavy durables in the kitchen.  Dancers Tad Tadlock and James Mitchell are the excellent dancing couple employing the style of 1950s musical production numbers, and they add a good deal of class and expertise to the business. (In fact, Mitchell had appeared as "Dream Curley" in the fantasy film sequence of 1955's OKLAHOMA!, subbing for the non-dancing Gordon MacRae.)As for Thelma ("Tad") Tadlock, she is just marvelous in both versions, but 1956's "Design for Dreaming," which is far more ambitious, campy and surrealistic than the 1961 follow-up, showcases her dancing better.  **SPOILER ALERT** An attempt to summarize: an unnamed young woman (I'll call her "Tad") is awakened by a mysterious masked man in evening clothes bearing an invitation to attend the 1956 Motorama at New York's Waldorf-Astoria Hotel (a real event which occupied all the hotel's ballrooms, 26,000 square feet). Tad floats to her destination "past a thousand windows yellow with light" and once there, marvels over the new cars from each GM division.Abruptly, though, the musical beat shifts from a perky boogie-woogie to a blues and the masked man carries her off to the kitchen -- it's very much the Fifties, gender-wise -- but at least it's the kitchen of the future, as brought to us by Frigidaire, then a GM subsidiary. After the ludicrously high-tech heavy appliances do their job (baking a cake almost automatically), Tad is whisked back to the Motorama and performs a primitivistic "Dance of Tomorrow" (tons of fog), after which, under fireworks and fanfare, GM's concept cars are introduced. Judge for yourself whether these models are handsome, daring, or just weird -- probably a mixture of all three.  Certainly the concept cars evoked admiration and comment from the Motorama-going public, and GM was smart enough to incorporate some names, styling tips and features into many of the company's real cars of the late Fifties.After this it gets even more Populuxe, when Tad and the masked stranger set out in the Car of Tomorrow (a concept "Firebird II" gull-winged roadster heavily laden with phallic imagery), over the electronic Highway of Tomorrow, where cars are controlled by radio towers. The Buildings of Tomorrow alone are worth the price of admission!  Naturally, when the old "Mystery Science Theater 3000" razzed this short, it proved ripe for satire and became a fan favorite ("While she's dancing the Japanese are making great cars!"). But "Design for Dreaming" deserves to be seen without the added sarcasm.  The irony of time and GM's corporate history provoke chagrin and nostalgia enough.All in all I highly recommended CLASSIC CAR COMMERCIALS AND AD SHORTS, which (despite the Firebird II) is suitable for all ages.

reviewText: this dvd only plays half way on all my dvd players. half way through it freeze. then it plays. then it freezes again. there is something wrong here. i never had this problem before. and also this dvd was a home made recording. the disc is not silver. its either a +r or -r recordable disc.

reviewText: There is nothing much I can add to the previous two reviews about dvd content but I'd just like to take this opportunity to mention dvd presentation. The dvd is in fact a DVD-R recordable dvd. There is absolutely no product information on the sleeve, which itself looks like a cut-and-paste amateur bootleg job that has been photo-copied (I guess graphic art isn't the distributor's forte). What you see here is the front cover of the dvd. The back is almost totally blank paper. No information on the inside either. The films themselves vary in quality but overall they are very good. I was surprised because the initial sight of the DVD-R left serious cause for doubt! ..but this is great stuff. Excellent nostalgia for petrol-heads.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a nice collection of car advertising from the mid-20th century, but the best is the short General Motors short film Design for Dreaming, which was featured in an episode of Mystery Science Theater. It tells of a young woman who visits the motorama, a sort of auto show of the time. But it's great because it's shear camp, a semi-musical, with such ridiculous lyrics like- girls don't goooo to motoramas, dressed in a pair of piiiiiink pajamas!This is only matched by the over the top dance stylings of Ms Tad Tadlock.She proceeds to sashay about the motorama, wanting every car.Finally, she is escorted into the Pontiac of tomorrow, a car Pontiac would never make, and drives off with her tuxedoed swain on the highway of tomorrow into a city that looks surprisingly like a kid's toy town.Great stuff. And, the short -A Touch of Magic- is similar and almost as goofy and, has Tad Tadlock again, creating another dancing storm. This time the theme is wizards and dragons, somehow it all ads up to a GM ad.Also the cartoons are interesting. You might even miss the fact that these cartoons were meant as automotive sales pitches. For instance, The Princess and the Pauper is an Aladdin type cartoon, in which the heroes magic carpet is transformed into a Chevy, of all things.
summary: Design For Dreaming is the best!
